			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Shareholder P<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">roposal Notice </font></b></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Provisions</font></b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The California Bylaws provide that a written notice containing the name of any person to be nominated by any shareholder for election as a director of the Company or containing any shareholder proposal to be presented at an upc<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">oming shareholders meeting must generally be received by the Secretary of the Company not less than 70 days prior to the first anniversary of the date the Company&rsquo;s proxy statement for the prior year&rsquo;s annual meeting was first released to shareholders</font><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">.</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The Delaware Bylaws contain notice provisions that are similar to those contained in the California Bylaws that require advance notice in order for a stockholder submitted director nomination or business proposal (other than proposals included in <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">DPW-Delaware&rsquo;s notice of meeting pursuant to Rule&nbsp;14a-8 promulgated under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) to be properly brought before a stockholder meeting. These notice provisions are similar to the provisions in the California Bylaws except that, to be timely, the notice must be generally delivered not earlier than the close of business on the 120<sup>th</sup><sup>&nbsp;</sup>day prior to such meeting and not later than the close of business on the later of the 90<sup>th</sup><sup>&nbsp;</sup>day prior to such meeting or the 10<sup>th</sup>&nbsp;day following the day on which public announcement is first made of the date of the meeting.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Change in Number of Directors</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under California law, a change in the number of directors must generally be approved by the shareholders, but the board of directors may fix the exact number of<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"> directors within a stated range set forth in the articles of incorporation or the bylaws, if the range has been approved by the shareholders.<br>
			<br>
			The California Bylaws provide that the number of directors of the Company shall not be less than five nor more than nine, with the exact number of directors to be fixed, within the limit specified, by approval of the board or the shareholders in the manner provided in the by-laws and Section 204(a) of the California&nbsp;Corporations Code.</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under the DGCL, the number <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">of directors will be fixed by or in the manner provided in the bylaws, unless the Delaware Certificate fixes the number of directors.</font></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The Delaware Certificate does not fix the number of directors, but provides that the Board may by resolution fix the numb<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">er of directors, subject to any minimum and maximum number of directors set forth in the Bylaws. </font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">26</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="TBL88" style="width: 100%; text-indent: 0px; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Classified Board</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The California <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Bylaws do not provide for a classified board. Instead, directors are elected annually.</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The Delaware Certificate does n<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">ot provide for a classified board. As a result, DPW-Delaware&rsquo;s directors will be elected annually.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Filling Vacancies on the Board</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The California Bylaws provide that vacancies on the Board not caused by removal may be filled by a majority of the directors then in office, regardless of whether they constitute a quorum, or by a sole remaining director. <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The shareholders may elect a director or directors at any time to fill&nbsp;any vacancy or vacancies not filled by the directors, but any such election&nbsp;other than to fill a vacancy created by removal, if by written consent,&nbsp;shall require the consent of the holders of a majority of the outstanding&nbsp;shares entitled to vote thereon</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The Delaware Bylaws provide that any vacancies on the Board shall<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">, subject to the right of the holders of any series of Preferred Stock and unless the Board otherwise determines, be filled solely by the affirmative vote of a majority of the directors then in office. </font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Removal of Directors</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under California law, any or all of the directors may be removed without cause if the removal is approved by the outstanding shares; <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><i>provided</i> that no director may be removed (unless the entire board is removed) when the votes cast against removal, or not consenting in writing to the removal, would be sufficient to elect the director if voted cumulatively at an election at which the same total number of votes were cast (or, if the action is taken by written consent, all shares entitled to vote were voted) and the entire number of directors authorized at the time of the director&rsquo;s most recent election were then being elected.</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under Delaware law, directors may be removed with<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"> or without cause, provided that directors may only be removed for cause if a corporation has either a classified board or cumulative voting. Because the DPW-Delaware Certificate does not establish a classified board or authorize cumulative voting, directors may be removed with or without cause.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Cumulative Voting; Vote Required</b></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>to Elect Directors; Majority Vote </b></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Standard</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The California Articles and the California Bylaws <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">do not provide for&nbsp;cumulative voting.&nbsp;</font></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">California law provides that if any shareholder has given notice of his or her intention to cumulate votes for the election of directors, all other shareholders of the corporation are also entitled to cumulate their votes at such election. In the absence <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">of such notification, directors are elected by a plurality of the votes cast. California law permits a corporation that is listed on a national securities exchange to amend its articles or bylaws to eliminate cumulative voting by approval of the board of directors and of the outstanding shares voting together as a single class.</font></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The Delaware Certificate does not provide for cumulative voting.<br>
			<br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under Delaware law, cumulative voting is not permitted unless a corporation provides for cumulative voting rights in its certificate of incorporation. The default voting standard for the election of directors under Delaware law is a plurality vote; however, the certificate of incorporation or bylaws may specify a different vote required for the election of directors.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">27</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="TBL88" style="width: 100%; text-indent: 0px; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Indemnification</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">California law requires indemnification when the indemnitee has defended the action successfully on the merits. Expenses incurred by an officer or director in defending an action may be paid in advance, if the director or officer undert<font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">akes to repay such amounts if it is ultimately determined that he or she is not entitled to indemnification. California law authorizes a corporation to purchase indemnity insurance for the benefit of its officers, directors, employees and agents whether or not the corporation would have the power to indemnify against the liability covered by the policy.</font><br>
			&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><br>
			<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The DGCL generally requires a corporation to indemnify a current or former director or officer against expenses incurred in defending a proc<font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">eeding related to such person&rsquo;s service to the corporation to the extent such person has been successful on the merits or otherwise in such proceeding. In addition, Delaware law generally provides that a corporation may indemnify, among others, its present and former directors and officers against expenses (including attorney&rsquo;s fees), judgments, fines and amounts paid in settlement of actions, if certain requirements are met including that the individual acted in good faith and in a manner reasonably believed to be in, or not opposed to, the best interests of the corporation; except that no indemnification may be paid for judgments and settlements in actions by or in the right of the corporation.</font></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">California law permits a corporation to provide rights to indemnification beyond those provided therein to the extent such additional indemnification is authorized in the corporation&rsquo;s articles of incorporation. Thus, if so authorized, rights to indemnification may be provided pursuant to agreements or bylaw provisions which make mandatory the permissive indemnification provided by California law.</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">A Delaware corporation generally may not indemnify a person against expenses to the extent the person is adjudged liable to the corporation.<br>
			&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The California Articles and Bylaws authorize indemnification to the fullest extent permissible under California law.</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The Delaware Bylaws generally provide that DPW-Delaware will indemnify, to the fullest extent authorized by the DGCL, among others, any person who was or is a party to any threatened, pending or completed action, suit or proceeding by reason of the fact that such person is or was a director or officer of the Company against all expense, liability and loss (including attorneys&rsquo; fees) incurred by such person in connection, therewith, subject to certain exceptions.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt;"><b>Elimination of Director Personal Liability for Monetary Damages</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">California law permits a corporation to eliminate the personal liability of directors for monetary damages, except where such liability is based on:</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The DGCL permits a corporation to eliminate the personal liability of directors for monetary damages, except where such liability is based on:</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Intentional misconduct or knowing and culpable violation of law;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Breaches of the director&rsquo;s duty of loyalty to the corporation or its shareholders;</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Acts or omissions that a director believes to be contrary to the best interests of the corporation or its shareholders or that involve the absence of good faith on the part of the director;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Acts or omissions not in good faith or involving intentional misconduct or knowing violations of law;</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Receipt of an improper personal benefit;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The payment of unlawful dividends or unlawful stock repurchases or redemption under Section&nbsp;174 of the DGCL; or</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Acts or omissions that show reckless disregard for the director&rsquo;s duty to the corporation or its shareholders, where the director in the ordinary course of performing a director&rsquo;s duties should be aware of a risk of serious injury to the corporation or its shareholders;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Transactions in which the director derived an improper personal benefit.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Acts or omissions that constitute an unexcused pattern of inattention that amounts to an abdication of the director&rsquo;s duty to the corporation and its shareholders;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">Such a limitation of liability provision also may not limit a director<font style="font-size: 10pt;">&rsquo;s liability for violation of, or otherwise relieve the Company or the directors from the necessity of complying with, federal or state securities laws, or affect the availability of non-monetary remedies such as injunctive relief or rescission.</font></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Transactions between the corporation and a director who has a material financial interest in such transaction; or</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Liability for improper distributions, loans or guarantees.</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The Delaware Certificate eliminates the liability of directors for monetary damages to the fullest extent permissible under the DGCL.</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The California Articles eliminate the liability of directors for monetary damages to the fullest extent permissible under California law.</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">28</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="TBL88" style="width: 100%; text-indent: 0px; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Dividends and Repurchases of Shares</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify;">Under California law, a corporation may not make any distribution to its shareholders or repurchase its shares unless either:</p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">The DGCL is more flexible than California law with <font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">respect to payment of dividends and the implementation of share repurchase programs. The DGCL generally provides that a corporation may redeem or repurchase its shares out of its surplus. Surplus is defined as the excess of a corporation&rsquo;s net assets (i.e.,&nbsp;its total assets minus its total liabilities) over a corporation&rsquo;s statutory capital, which the Board may generally increase or decrease by resolution, subject to a statutory requirement that at a minimum a corporation&rsquo;s capital must equal the aggregate par value of its issued shares.</font></td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The amount of retained earnings of the corporation immediately prior to the distribution or payment of the price of the shares being repurchased equals or exceeds the sum of (i)&nbsp;the amount of the proposed distribution, <i>plus</i> (ii)the preferential dividends arrears amount, if any; or</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Immediately after the distribution or share repurchase, the value of the corporation&rsquo;s assets would equal or exceed the sum of its total liabilities, <i>plus</i> the preferential rights amount, if any.</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">For purposes of determining whether a California corporation meets either of these tests, the determination may be based on any of the following:</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The corporation&rsquo;s financial statements;</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">A fair valuation; or</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&bull;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;"><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Any other method that is reasonable under the circumstances.</font></td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">These tests are applied to California corporations on a consolidated basis.</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 33%; vertical-align: top;">&nbsp;</td>
		</tr>
		<tr>
			<td style="width: 30%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Dissolution</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">Under California law, holders of 50% or more of a corporation<font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">&rsquo;s total voting power may authorize the corporation&rsquo;s dissolution, with or without approval of the corporation&rsquo;s board of directors, and this right may not be modified by the articles of incorporation.</font><br>
			&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td colspan="2" rowspan="1" style="width: 1%; text-align: justify; vertical-align: top;">Under the DGCL, unless the Board of Directors approves the proposal to dissolve, the dissolution must be unanimously approved by all the stockholders entitled to vote on the matter. Only if the dissol<font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">ution is initially approved by the Board of Directors may the dissolution be approved by a simple majority of the outstanding shares entitled to vote. The DGCL allows a Delaware corporation to include in its certificate of incorporation a supermajority voting requirement in connection with such a board-initiated dissolution, but the Delaware</font><font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="text-align: justify; font-size: 10pt;">Certificate contains no such supermajority voting requirement.</font></td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">29</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="TBL88" style="width: 100%; text-indent: 0px; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 29.7%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Forum Selection</b></p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34.2%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Not addressed.</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 1.1%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="width: 34%; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Delaware courts have upheld the right of Delaware corporations to <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">include forum selection provisions in their bylaws. Such provisions normally provide that shareholders bringing derivative claims or claims alleging breaches of fiduciary duties arising from the DGCL or otherwise implicating the internal affairs of the corporation be brought exclusively in Delaware state or federal courts.</font></p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

			<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Under the Delaware Certificate, unless we consent in writing to the selection of an alternative forum, the Delaware Court of Chancery will be the sole and exclusive forum for any derivat<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">ive action or proceeding brought on behalf of the corporation, any action asserting a claim of breach of a fiduciary duty owed by any director, officer, other employee or stockholder of the corporation to the corporation or the corporation&rsquo;s stockholders, any action asserting a claim arising pursuant to any provision of the DGCL or as to which the DGCL confers jurisdiction upon the Delaware Court of Chancery, any action asserting a claim arising pursuant to any provision of our Delaware Certificate or Delaware Bylaws, or any action asserting a claim governed by the internal affairs doctrine.</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>Interest of the Company</b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>&rsquo;</b><b>s Directors and Executive Officers in the Reincorporation </b></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">The shareholders should be aware that certain of our directors and executive officers may have interests in the transaction that are different from, or in addition to, the interests of the shareholders generally. For example, the Reincorporation may provide officers and directors of the Corporation with more clarity and certainty in the reduction of their potential personal liability in their fiduciary roles for the Corporation, and to strengthen the ability of directors to resist takeover bids on behalf of shareholders. The Board has considered these interests, among other matters, in reaching its decision to recommend that our shareholders vote in favor of this proposal<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Consequences </b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">The following discussion summarizes certain U.S. federal income tax consequences of the Reincorporation to holders of our <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Common Stock. The discussion is based on the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the &ldquo;<b>Code</b>&rdquo;), regulations promulgated under the Code by the U.S. Treasury Department (including proposed and temporary regulations), rulings, current administrative interpretations and official pronouncements of the Internal Revenue Service (the &ldquo;<b>IRS</b>&rdquo;), and judicial decisions, all as currently in effect and all of which are subject to differing interpretations or to change, possibly with retroactive effect. Such change could materially and adversely affect the U.S. federal income tax consequences described below. No assurance can be given that the IRS would not assert, or that a court would not sustain, a position contrary to any of the tax consequences described herein. </font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">30</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">This discussion is for general information only, and does not purport to discuss all aspects of U.S. federal income taxation that may be important to a particular holder in light of its investment or tax circumstances or to holders subject to special tax rules, such as partnerships, subchapter S corporations or other pass-through entities (and investors in such entities), banks, financial institutions, tax-exempt entities, insurance companies, regulated investment companies, real estate investment trusts, trusts and estates, dealers in stocks, securities or currencies, traders in securities that have elected to use the mark-to-market method of accounting for their securities, persons<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"> </font><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">holding our Common Stock as part of an integrated transaction, including a &ldquo;straddle,&rdquo; &ldquo;hedge,&rdquo; &ldquo;constructive sale,&rdquo; or &ldquo;conversion transaction,&rdquo; persons whose functional currency for tax purposes is not the U.S. dollar, former citizens or residents of the United States, persons who acquired our Common Stock pursuant to the exercise of stock options or otherwise as compensation, persons who hold our Common Stock as qualified small business stock within the meaning of Section 1202 of the Code and persons subject to the alternative minimum tax provisions of the Code. This discussion does not address any U.S. federal taxes (other than U.S. federal income taxes), any state or local taxes, or of any foreign taxes, that may be applicable to a particular holder. </font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">This discussion is directed solely to holders that hold our <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Common Stock as capital assets within the meaning of Section 1221 of the Code, which generally means as property held for investment. In addition, the following discussion only addresses &ldquo;U.S. persons&rdquo; for U.S. federal income tax purposes, generally defined as beneficial owners of our Common Stock who are, for U.S. federal income tax purposes:</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="MTAB89" style="width: 100%; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 36pt;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 18pt; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&bull;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Individuals who are citizens or <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">residents of the United States;</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 54pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="MTAB90" style="width: 100%; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 36pt;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 18pt; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&bull;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Corporations created or organized in or under the laws of the United States or of any state of the United Stat<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">es or the District of Columbia;</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="MTAB91" style="width: 100%; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 36pt;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 18pt; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&bull;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Estates the income of which is subject to U.S. federal income tax<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">ation regardless of its source;</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="MTAB92" style="width: 100%; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 36pt;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 18pt; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&bull;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Trusts if a court within the United States is able to exercise primary supervision over the administration of any such trust and one or more U.S. persons have the authority to control all substantial decisions of such t<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">rust; or</font></p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt 0pt 0pt 36pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" id="MTAB93" style="width: 100%; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">

		<tr>
			<td style="width: 36pt;">&nbsp;</td>
			<td style="width: 18pt; vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&bull;</p>
			</td>
			<td style="vertical-align: top;">
			<p style="text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 0pt; margin-right: 0pt; margin-bottom: 0pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Trusts in existence on August 20, 1996 that have valid elections in effect under applicable Treasury regulations to be treated as U.S. persons.</p>
			</td>
		</tr>

</table>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">If an entity or arrangement treated as a partnership for U.S. federal income tax purposes holds our <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Common Stock, the U.S. federal income tax treatment of a partner generally will depend on the status of the partner and the activities of the partnership. A partner of a partnership holding our Common Stock should consult its own tax advisor regarding the U.S. federal income tax consequences to the partner of the Reincorporation. </font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>This discussion does not purport to be a complete analysis of all of the Reincorporation</b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>&rsquo;</b><b>s tax consequences that may be relevant to holders. We urge you to consult your own tax advisor regarding your particular circumstances and the U.S. federal income and other federal tax consequences to you of the Reincorporation, as well as any tax consequences arising under the laws of any state, local, foreign or other tax jurisdiction and the possible effects of changes in U.S. federal or other tax laws.</b></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">We have not requested a ruling from the IRS or an opinion of counsel regarding the U.S. federal income tax consequences of the Reincorporation. <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">However, the Reincorporation is intended to qualify as a tax-free reorganization under Section 368(a) of the Code. Assuming that the Reincorporation qualifies as a tax-free reorganization under Section 368(a) of the Code, and subject to the qualifications and assumptions described in this proxy statement: (a) holders of DPW-California Common Stock will not recognize any gain or loss as a result of the consummation of the Reincorporation, (b) the aggregate tax basis of the DPW-Delaware Common Stock held by each holder immediately following the consummation of the Reincorporation will equal the aggregate tax basis of the DPW-California Common Stock converted therefor and (c) the holding period of the DPW-Delaware Common Stock held by each holder following the consummation of the Reincorporation will include the period during which such holder held the DPW-California Common Stock converted therefor.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);"><b>Required Vote</b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b> and Board Recommendation</b></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Approval <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">of the proposed change in corporate domicile from California to Delaware requires the receipt of the affirmative vote of the holders of a majority of the Company&rsquo;s issued and outstanding shares of Common Stock as of the Record Date.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255);">Shareholders are urged to read this proposal carefully<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">, including all of the related Exhibits attached to this Proxy Statement, before voting on Shareholder approval of the Reincorporation. The discussion above is qualified in its entirety by the Merger Agreement in substantially the form attached hereto as Appendix B, the Delaware Certificate in substantially the form attached hereto as Appendix C, and the Delaware Bylaws in substantially the form attached hereto as Appendix D.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>The Board unanimously recommends a vote </b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>&ldquo;</b><b>FOR</b><b>&rdquo;</b><b> the approval of the </b><b>proposed change in corporate domicile from</b><b> California to Delaware</b></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">31</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>PROPOSAL NO. 4</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>APPROVAL OF</b><font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b> THE </b><b>CONVERSION </b><b>OF UP TO 500,000 SHARES OF SERIES B PREFERRED STOCK </b><b>INTO SHARES OF COMMON STOCK </b><b>AND </b><b>THE EXERCISE OF </b><b>WARRANTS TO PURCHASE SHARES OF COMMON STOCK </b><b>IN </b><b>ORDER TO </b><b>COMPLY WITH R</b><b>ULE 713 OF THE NYSE AMERICAN</b></font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>&nbsp;</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Terms of the Transaction</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">On March 9, 2017, the Company entered into a Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement (the <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&ldquo;<b>Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement</b>&rdquo;) with Philou Ventures, LLC (&ldquo;<b>Philou</b>&rdquo;). Philou is the Company&rsquo;s largest shareholder and Kristine Ault, a director of the Company, controls and is a Manager of Philou. Pursuant to the terms of the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement, Philou will invest up to $5,000,000 in the Company through the purchase of Series B Convertible Preferred Stock (the &ldquo;<b>Series B </b><b>Preferred Stock</b>&rdquo;) over the Term, as specified herein. In addition, for each share of Series B Preferred Stock purchased by Philou, Philou will receive warrants (the &ldquo;<b>Series B </b><b>Warrants</b>&rdquo;) to purchase shares of Common Stock in a number equal to the stated value of each share of Series B Preferred Stock of $10.00 purchased divided by $0.70 at an exercise price equal to $0.70 per share of Common Stock (the &ldquo;<b>Series B Conversion Price</b>&rdquo;). In connection with the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement, the Company entered into a registration rights agreement with Philou.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">For each share of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock purchased by Philou, Philou will receive a Series B Warrant to purchase shares of Common Stock in a number equal to the stated value of all shares of Series B Preferred Stock sold divided by $0.70 for an exercise price equal to $0.70 per share (the &ldquo;<b>Series B Warrant Exercise Price</b>&rdquo;). The exercise period will begin on the six month after, and end on the fifth year and six month anniversary of, the date of issuance. The exercise price of the Series B Warrant is subject to adjustment for stock splits, stock dividends, combinations or similar events. The Series B Warrant may be exercised for cash or, upon the failure to maintain an effective registration statement, on a cashless basis.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Pursuant to the <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement, the Company agreed to recommend that its shareholders approve the Reincorporation at its next annual meeting. In addition, the Company agreed to use its best efforts to obtain its shareholders&rsquo; approval, pursuant to NYSE American Rule 713, for the actions contemplated by the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement as soon as possible.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Each share of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock shall be purchased at $10.00 up to a maximum issuance of 500,000 shares of Series B Preferred Stock. Philou guaranteed that it would purchase, no later than May 31, 2017, the greater of: (i) 100,000 shares of Series B Preferred Stock or (ii) a sufficient number of shares of Series B Preferred Stock to ensure that the Company has sufficient stockholders&rsquo; equity to meet the minimum continued listing standards of the NYSE American. Philou has purchased 100,000 shares of Series B Preferred Stock. In addition, for as long as any shares of Series B Preferred Stock remain outstanding during the Term, Philou agreed to purchase additional shares of Series B Preferred Stock in a sufficient amount in order for the Company to meet the NYSE American&rsquo;s minimum stockholders&rsquo; equity continued listing requirement subject to the maximum number of 500,000 shares of Series B Preferred Stock (collectively, &ldquo;<b>Guaranteed Purchases</b>&rdquo;). In addition, at any time during the Term, Philou may, in its sole and absolute discretion, purchase additional shares of Series B Preferred Stock, up to the 500,000 share maximum (&ldquo;<b>Voluntary Purchases</b>&rdquo;). All consideration for Voluntary Purchases shall be delivered through a series of varying payments (&ldquo;<b>Payments</b>&rdquo;) by Philou, at its sole and absolute discretion, during the period commencing on the closing date and ending 36 months therefrom (the &ldquo;<b>Term</b>&rdquo;). The Company shall have the right to request, with 90-day written notice to Philou, that Guaranteed Purchases be accelerated to meet deadlines for maintaining the minimum stockholders&rsquo; equity required by the NYSE American. The Series B Preferred Stock shall not be callable by the Company for 25 years from the closing date.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Pursuant to the Preferred Stock Purchase Agreement<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">, at any time while no fewer than one hundred thousand (100,000) Series B Preferred Stock are issued and outstanding and held by Philou, Philou shall have the right to participate in the Company&rsquo;s future financings under substantially the same terms and conditions as other investors in those respective financings in order to maintain its then percentage ownership interest in the Company. Philou&rsquo;s right to participate in such financings shall accrue and accumulate provided that it still owns at least 100,000 shares of Series B Preferred Stock.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">I<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">n order to comply with NYSE American Rule 713, Philou may not (i) vote the shares of Series B Preferred Stock; (ii) convert such shares of Series B Preferred Stock into shares of Common Stock or (iii) exercise its rights under the Series B Warrant until the requirement of NYSE American Rule 713 has been met at a meeting, or by the requisite written consent, of the holders of the outstanding shares of Common Stock.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<div id="PGBK" style="width: 100%; margin-right: 0pt; margin-left: 0pt;">
<div id="PGNUM" style="width: 100%; text-align: center; font-family: Times New Roman; font-size: 10pt;">32</div>

<hr style="border: currentColor; border-image: none; width: 100%; height: 2px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); page-break-after: always; background-color: rgb(0, 0, 0);">
<div id="PGHDR" style="width: 100%; text-align: left;">&nbsp;</div>
</div>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: left; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Description of the Series B Preferred Stock</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Each share of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock has a stated value of $10.00 per share and may be convertible at the holder&rsquo;s option into shares of Common Stock of the Company at a conversion rate of $0.70 per share, subject to customary adjustment, upon the earlier to occur of: (i) 60 months from the closing date, or (ii) upon the filing by the Company of one or more periodic reports that, singly or collectively, evidence(s) that the Company&rsquo;s gross revenues have reached no less than $10,000,000 in the aggregate, on a consolidated reporting basis, over four consecutive quarters in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">The <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Conversion Price will be subject to standard anti-dilution provisions in connection with any stock split, stock dividend, subdivision or similar reclassification of the Common Stock.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Each share of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock shall have the right to receive dividends equal to one ten millionth (0.0000001) of the Company&rsquo;s EBITDAS calculated for a particular calendar year. Assuming the purchase of the entire $5,000,000 of shares of Series B Preferred Stock, the holders thereof will be entitled to receive dividends equal to five percent (5%) in the aggregate of EBITDAS. Payment of dividends shall be calculated for a calendar year, payable on a quarterly basis, with payments to occur no later than 90 days in arrears from each reporting period subject to a year-end reconciliation. EBITDAS shall mean earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortization, and stock-based compensation.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Philou shall have the right to designate a number of directors to the Company<font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&rsquo;s Board of Directors equal to a percentage determined by the number of shares of Series B Preferred Stock (determined on an &ldquo;as converted&rdquo; basis) divided by the sum of the number of shares of Common Stock outstanding plus the number of shares of Series B Preferred Stock outstanding as determined on an as converted basis. Philou&rsquo;s percentage to designate a number of directors shall be determined each time Philou makes a purchase of shares of Series B Preferred Stock and cannot be decreased unless Philou converts or sells all or part of its shares of Series B Preferred Stock, in which case the number of directors that Philou may designate will be re-calculated. The right to designate a director shall be a contractual right granted to Philou and not to any potential subsequent owner of shares of Series B Preferred Stock.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">In the case for the election of directors, the <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock shall be voted on an &ldquo;as converted&rdquo; basis together with the Common Stock. In all other cases, the Series B Preferred Stock shall be voted in accordance with California law.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Each share of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock shall have dividend and liquidation rights in priority to any shares of Common Stock, the Company&rsquo;s Series A Preferred Stock (of which none are outstanding) and other subordinated securities.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">At such time as (i) all shares of Common Stock issuable upon conversion of all outstanding shares of <font style="font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">Series B Preferred Stock (the &ldquo;<b>Series B </b><b>Conversion Shares</b>&rdquo;) shall have been registered for resale pursuant to an effective Registration Statement covering such Series B Conversion Shares, (ii) but no earlier than the twenty-fifth (25<sup>th</sup>) anniversary of the effective date, the shares of Series B Preferred Stock shall be subject to redemption in cash at the option of the Company in an amount per share equal to 120% of the greater of (a) the stated value plus all accrued and unpaid dividends, if any and (b) the fair market value of such shares of Series B Preferred Stock.</font></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 36pt; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;"><b>Why the Company Needs Shareholder Approval</b></p>

<p style="margin: 0pt; text-align: justify; font-family: Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size: 10pt;">&nbsp;</p>
